control.translation[0].definitions[0].si: make somebody/something do what you want
control.translation[0].definitions[0].de: the ability or power to make someone or something do what you want or make something happen in the way you want
control.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The disease robs you of muscle control.
Artists like to have some control over where their works are hung in a gallery.
She’s a good teacher who has control of her class.
Students are encouraged to take control of their own learning, rather than just depending on the teacher.
Excessive drinking can make you lose control of your own life.
‘Do you need any help?’ ‘No. It’s under control, thanks.’
Dogs are allowed on the trails if they are kept under control.
The car spun out of control and hit a tree.
Flight delays do occur, for reasons that are outside our control.
Babies are born with very little control over their movements.
control.translation[0].definitions[1].de: the power to make the decisions about how a country, place, company etc is organized or what it does
control.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The press was freed from political control.
By the end of the year, the rebels had control over the northern territories.
The Johnson family has effective control of the company, owning almost 60% of the shares.
China gained control of the island in 1683.
His son is being trained to take control of the family business.
The Democrats lost control of Congress in the last election.
The Conservatives are hoping to regain control of the city council.
Jordan asked for editorial control of the project.
Anti-government forces are still in control of the area.
The college was under the control of a group of trustees.
The whole of this area came under Soviet control after World War II.
control.translation[0].definitions[2].de: an action, method, or law that limits the amount or growth of something, especially something that is dangerous
control.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: an agreement on arms control (=control of the amount of weapons a country has)
Police used fire hoses and dogs for crowd control.
Rent controls ensured that no one paid too much for housing.
the introduction of tighter controls on immigration
The authorities imposed strict controls on the movement of cattle.
Firefighters had the blaze under control by 9:44 p.m.
Shea used diet and exercise to bring her weight under control.
The Federal Reserve Bank raised interest rates to keep inflation under control.
control.translation[0].definitions[3].de: the ability to remain calm even when you feel very angry, upset, or excited
control.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: There were sudden tears in his eyes and he paused, fighting for control.
Davidson lost control of himself and started yelling.
Small children can’t be expected to have the same self-control (=ability to control their emotions and behaviour) as an adult.
Her voice is under control, but she is almost shaking with anger.
I felt calm and in control.
control.translation[0].definitions[4].de: the thing that you press or turn to make a machine, vehicle, television etc work
control.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: the volume control on the radio
Belton, at the controls, made a perfect landing.
control.translation[0].definitions[5].de: the people who direct an activity or who check that something is done correctly, the place where this is done, or the process of doing it
control.translation[0].definitions[6].de: a person, group etc against which you compare another person or group that is very similar, in order to see if a particular quality is caused by something or happens by chance
control.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: A control group of non-smoking women was compared to four groups of women smokers.
control.translation[0].definitions[7].de: a thing that you already know the result for that is used in a scientific test, in order to show that your method is working correctly
control.translation[0].definitions[8].de: a particular button on a computer that allows you to do certain operations
control.translation[0].definitions[8].ex: Press control and F2 to exit.
control.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to have the power to make the decisions about how a country, place, company etc is organized or what it does
control.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: The Democrats continued to control the Senate until last year.
a huge company controlling half the world’s coffee trade
control.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to limit the amount or growth of something, especially something that is dangerous
control.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: a chemical used to control weeds
an economic plan to control inflation
Development in areas of outstanding natural beauty is strictly controlled.
Strict measures were taken to control the spread of foot and mouth disease.
control.translation[1].definitions[2].si: make somebody/something do what you want
control.translation[1].definitions[2].de: to make someone or something do what you want, or make something happen in the way that you want
control.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: Police had to be called in to control the crowds.
a skilled rider controlling a spirited horse
control.translation[1].definitions[3].de: if you control your emotions, your voice, your expression etc, you succeed in behaving calmly and sensibly, even though you feel angry, upset, or excited
control.translation[1].definitions[3].ex: Sarah took a deep breath, trying to control her anger.
He controlled the urge to laugh.
Newman controlled himself with an effort.
control.translation[1].definitions[4].de: to make a machine, process, or system work in a particular way
control.translation[1].definitions[4].ex: A thermostat controls the temperature in the building.
The valves in the heart control how quickly the blood is pumped around the body.
control.translation[1].definitions[5].de: to make sure that something is done correctly
control.translation[1].definitions[5].ex: The company strictly controls the quality of its products.
control.translation[1].note_box[0].secti: to have power over a country, place, company etc, and decide what happens there
The Democrats controlled the US Congress.
Government forces now control the city.
to make the important everyday decisions concerning a company, organization, country etc, so that it can continue to operate
He runs a software company in New York.
The parents want to run the school themselves.
The government is unfit to run the country.
The charity runs a medical clinic in one of the poorest parts of the city.
be in charge of somebody/something
to have control over something, or responsibility for a group of people
She is in charge of training new employees.
I left him in charge of the children while I was out.
manage
to be in charge of a company, especially one that someone else owns
In 1963, she opened a furniture store, and her son has managed it since 1985.
be in power
if a group or leader is in power, they have political control of a country
Abe resigned after less than a year in power.
It was the first time a democratically elected government had been in power.
rule
if a leader or political group rules a country, they have political control of that country
President Assad ruled the country for almost 30 years.
The same party has ruled Japan for many years.
supervise
to be in charge of a group of workers or students and make sure that they do their work properly
Professor Braude supervised the research team.
He’s supervising the building work.
control.translation[2].definitions[0].de: an action taken to make sure that something does not increase too much
control.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: Devaluations were combined with wage and price controls and reductions in state spending.
Private rented accommodation has been freed of rent controls, taking it beyond the reach of the young homeless.
control.translation[2].definitions[1].de: if someone has control of shares in a company, they own them
control.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: Krupp said it had control of other blocks of Hoesch shares.
control.translation[2].definitions[2].de: if someone has control of a company, they own more than half its shares, or enough shares to be able to decide how the company is managed
control.translation[2].definitions[2].ex: CFS and Mr Vernes were battling for control of the Victoire insurance group.
Publicis purchased a little over 50% of Inovasi to gain control.
India is to sell stakes in state-owned companies to overseas investors while retaining majority control.
control.translation[2].definitions[3].de: a button on a computer that allows you to do operations when used with another button
control.translation[2].definitions[3].ex: Press control D to delete text.
control.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to have the power to make someone or something do what you want
control.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: U.S. offices of foreign banks now control roughly a quarter of U.S. banking assets.
The government controls the production and distribution of all national newspapers.
control.translation[3].definitions[1].de: to limit something or prevent it from increasing too much
control.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: To help control costs, the company cut salaries by between 2% and 25% last month.
Romania will control skyrocketing food prices by setting ceilings for items such as meat.
control.translation[3].definitions[2].de: to check that something is as it should be
control.translation[3].definitions[2].ex: Checkers control the quality of products as they come off the production line.
control.translation[3].definitions[3].ex: Mr Kahn now controls 854,236 common shares, or about 40% of Mercury’s stock.
control.translation[3].definitions[4].de: to own more than half the shares of a company, or enough shares to decide how the company should be managed
control.translation[3].definitions[4].ex: The Agnelli family controls the car group through a variety of holding companies.
control.translation[3].definitions[5].de: if a company or product controls a particular part of a market, its products account for a large amount of the sales in that market
control.translation[3].definitions[5].ex: De Beers controls 80% of the rough, uncut diamond market.
